720400f-a.text:
E.  2922e :
The Seventy-First Regiment Armory, Broadway, east side, from
35th to 36th Streets.
About 1890.

720399f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, north from West 35th Street (Right) showing prominently the newly erected Herald Building. This replaced the old 71st Irf. Regiment Armory. Note the absence of the tri-figured "Bell Ringers" that was mounted in 1895 atop the Herald Building.
About 1893-4
H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection  De0 aWGW:

717410f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, from West 35th to 36th Street's, showing prominently the Herald Square Theatre. This is at the N.W. corner of 35th Street. It was first opened in 1883 as the New Park. Later Harrigan took a lease and produced "01d Lavender","Pote" and other successes. The name was changed to that shown in 1895. The following year Belasco's play 'The Heart of Maryland" was produced here. Lew Fields was the final lessee. The house
was torn down in 1912.
At the left and right margins respectively appear Macy's Department Store and the Hotel Marlborough. Slightly to the right of the former is the Arsenal tower at Seventh Ave.
About 1910
H. N. Tiemenn, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection
Ne,. 2917

717428f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, from 37th to 35th Streets. The left building nearing completion has replaced four two- and four-story The Sheridan Building and the corner building at 36th Street been demolished, and the Greenwich Savings Bank is under construction
on their former site.
1922.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

720398f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, north from Weat 35th Street. It is at this point (34th Street), that Broadway intersects Sixth Ave. A Broadway Street Car is shown in the foreground. Building under construction is the new Rogers Peet and Company Building on 36th Street, between Broadway
and Sixth Ave.
April 1929.
Eugene L. Armbruster, Collection.

717408f.text:
Broadway, east side, at W. 35th Street, showing subway construc tion actibity at Herald Square. Sixth Avenue and its "E1" line are on the left. This transportation facitlity is shortly to disappear.
1938-9
Alexander Alland
This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N. Y." by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.

712245f-a.text:
(1) 35th Street, north side, from east of Sixth Avenue to Broadway, looking across Herald Square. The Garrick Theatre (which first opened in 1890, as Harrigan's Theatre) stands at No. 63, adjoining the clearing at the corner of Sixth Avenue where a sixteen-story bank building will rise.

February 11, 1930
P. L. Sperr
Neg. #2414

(2) The same, a closer view. The theatre will shortly be demolished.

February 22, 1930
P.S. Sperr

(2) The same, a closer view. The theatre will shortly be demolished.

717412f-a.text:
Broadway, at the N. W. corner of West 35th Street, showing the New Park Theatre, opened in 1883, and which in 1895 became the Herald Scuare Theatre.
About 1885
Gift of Urbrock Collection
Nea ~ 11h0

717411f-a.text:
The Johnson Building, Broadway, west side, from 35th to
36th Streets.
January 30, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
